main event: On May 6, 1956, an observer in Oklahoma City reported seeing a single bright object described as resembling a star, specifically Capella, which exhibited atmospheric distortion and twinkling conditions.
interesting points: The object had a slight orange tint and emitted bright light,Several witnesses reported seeing the object, which was estimated to be at an elevation of 320 degrees and about 1 mile away from the observer's location.,The object was visible for approximately 30 minutes, during which it seemed to hover and move erratically.,The sighting coincided with a weather balloon release, but no balloons were identified at the time of the sighting.,Initial assessments suggested the phenomenon might be an optical illusion or a celestial body, such as Jupiter, rather than an aircraft or UFO.
sighted object: a single bright light resembling the star Capella
witness description: Observers included a father and son who were driving along a country road and noted the unusual object's movements.
